content.description:
Nihil notabilenotabilis, -e, adj.: noteworthy secutum, nisi forte quod non fui reusreus, -i, m.: an accused man;
futurus, si Domitianus sub quo haec acciderunt diutius 
vixisset. Nam in scrinioscrinium, -i, n.: desk eius datus a CaroCarus, -i, m.: Carus (a Roman male name) de me libelluslibellus, -i, m.: written accusation 
inventus est.
content.question: According to the passage, for which of the following reasons did Pliny not have to stand trial?

choices.label: Carus was found to be guilty by Domitian instead of Pliny.
Carus failed to locate the evidence that proved Pliny’s guilt.
Pliny was able to convict Carus before Carus could accuse Pliny.
Domitian had died before reading Carus’s accusation against Pliny.

content.answer: Domitian had died before reading Carus’s accusation against Pliny.

unit.text: 3: Pliny's Letters: Ghosts and Apparitions, Letters to Trajan and Calpurnia, and Teacher's Choice - Latin Prose
